Crossword Revolution Day 30: DUTY/PLEASURE

Last day (for now) for the Crossword Revolution.  I‚Äôm torn between Tagore and Nash‚Äôs takes on DUTY and PLEASURE:

I slept and dreamt
that life was joy.
I awoke and saw
that life was duty.
I worked ‚Äî and behold,
duty was joy.

‚ÄìRabindranath Tagore

O Duty, 
Why hast thou not the visage of a sweetie or a cutie?
Why glitter thy spectacles so ominously?
Why art thou clad so abominously?
Why art thou so different from Venus
And why do thou and I have so few interests mutually in common between us?
Why art thou fifty per cent martyr
And fifty-one per cent Tartar?

Thou so ubiquitous,
And I so iniquitous . . .

- Ogden Nash, from Kind of an Ode to Duty

Not to be ‚Äúthat guy‚Äù but 54-DOWN is quite wrong. Though 2001 famously has a long prologue with just apes there are two glaring errors in the clue: ‚ÄúOnly character shown in the first 30 minutes of ‚Äò2001: A Space Odyssey‚Äô ‚Äú. 

A) the prologue ends at about the 20-minutes mark, when we do start to see modern humans. Including the main character of the first act (see B) but also ancillary characters like pilots and flight attendants. 

B) while Dave is the famous non-computer character from the movie [HAL: Just what do you think you're doing, Dave?], Dave doesn‚Äôt show up until the Jupiter mission at about 55-min in. The character in the first act, the moon mission, is Floyd. 

It could be argued, then, that Floyd (or Haywood) would be the intended answer, since non of the other humans are really named or important in that first 30-min.

Just a general comment on solve times. I almost always finish faster than my average solve time. I think this is because when a puzzle is particularly problematic it takes a LOT longer to solve. So my solve times for a given day (hypothetically) could be 10, 10, 10, 10, 10, and 50. The average solve time for that day is therefore 100/6 = 16 minutes and 40 seconds. Then the next week I solve it again in 10 minutes and think it's "easy" because I beat my average by over 6 minutes. More useful would be to know our MEDIAN solve times for each day -- that would give a better sense of when a puzzle is "easy."

@Jane Wheelaghan 

A zip keeps your trousers up in the UK, but here in the States, a zipper keeps your pants up.

We don't call it a zip, although the verb is zip.

A zip code is a postal code.  It replaced one- and two-digit zones in cities, and in fact, replaced the "City, State" part of an address from the point of view of the post office (although those items are still traditionally included, if they are omitted, the mail would still get there.)  So the "zip" of zip code is actually an acronym for "zone improvement plan".

But zip is also slang for ZERO, or as they say across the pond, nought.

As I'm sure you have figured out, the home plate UMPire in baseball calls balls and strikes (as we discussed just a day ago) during a batter's turn at bat.  A strike is a pitch in the strike zone that the batter doesn't attempt to hit, one he swings at and misses, or hits foul (except for the third strike, or that is caught on the fly by any fielder).  As of just last year, a strike can be called against a batter who is not ready in the prescribed amount of time for the next pitch.  A ball is a pitch outside the strike zone that the batter doesn't attempt to hit.  Four balls is a walk (free pass to first base); three strikes, and the batter is out.

Again, probably more than you wanted to know about baseball.  Or zip codes.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

I think that in the sense of swinging at and missing a ball pitched at you, it's called a strike because it's a mark against you.  Like vertical lines written on a wall.

But of course, you're right about it making "zip" sense, inasmuch as our local Mets announcer frequently calls a hit that has been hit hard a "well-struck hit".

But of course, a pitch out of the strike zone is called a ball, and so is the object that is pitched.

It‚Äôs a bit of a pain, but you might want to create an account at xwstats.com. 

Here‚Äôs how they calculate averages:

Average solve times are actually rolling averages for that day of the week. Since puzzle solve times are likely to vary by day and over time, we use a 10 day rolling average to compute your average solve time for a given day. For example, the average solve time on a random Saturday would be the average of the 10 previous Saturday solve times before that. If you're getting better, you'll notice your average solve times decreasing over time.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî
Interestingly, when they compare your time to other solvers, they use the median solving time, not the mean.

All are nodes on networks, that is, connections on those networks.  Just as quilts are one form of blanket.

@HeathieJ 

I found this one easier than I anticipated. It seemed very hard at first, but then things started to fall in place in clumps, each clump after a bit of a struggle.

The theme was definitely helpful, which I always appreciate.

But I get what you are saying, as that is my experience too. Sometimes a puzzle is just too hard for me, and then I read the comments and find that I am mostly alone.

And while my ego can get pretty bruised, which is not fun, I find solace in knowing when to give up. 

Sometimes, after going around in circles for five or ten minutes, I get the sense that it is time to give up, which I hate to do. And when I do the reveal, I see that the one or two places I was struggling with would never have come to me, and I feel a bit of satisfaction at not having continued a fruitless struggle.

But today, my random bits of vaguely remembered tidbits, such as the Olmec being a mesoamerican culture, came in handy.  Kind of made up for me never hearing about that guy with an idea about a canal that showed up in January.

@Lily

Like you, I can't remember the last time I wasn't able to make a Thursday work without any help. Couldn't believe it! 

I appreciate knowing I'm not alone!  :-)

@Renegator 

OH, that's right... the man with the plan! Fun with palindromes. 

Thanks for sharing your experience. And you're right, ultimately, I was glad I revealed. I rarely do it, I can almost always figure it out in the end... I have a hard time giving up on things, just generally speaking, but when I saw the revealed answers, I knew I'd have never finished. 

As much as I love doing these puzzles, I am learning that if one is such a struggle and not a fun struggle anymore (again, rare) I don't have to keep going. It's not a job or other responsibilities, I can just stop. 

I've realized that with reading too. For my first four decades, I suppose, I felt I had to finish a book no matter how I disliked it. I'd trudge through at any cost hoping and expecting it to improve and be justified.

At some point, I was reading a book that I hated so much and found that I actively didn't care what happened to any of the horrible people in it, and I couldn't imagine there was any redemption to be had, so I (shockingly) decided to be done and my last decade or so of reading has been much better for it. Fortunately, hating a book also doesn't happen often because I like a lot of different things. :-)

Anyhow, sounds a bit silly, but that was a big thing for me.   My stick-to-itiveness has been with me kind of to a fault, so it's kind of freeing to give myself a bit more grace as I age.. even if it's just with books and puzzles.  :-)

I was like, "Wait, what? You can do that?!?!"

What a revelation. But like you, I tend to hate giving up on something I have started. It actually has paid off over the years career-wise.
